title: DoorDash's 2021 Revenue Tops Pandemic Record; Food-delivery company sees continued growth this year
text:
DoorDash Inc.'s revenue and order volume last year topped 2020's levels, showing food-delivery's resilience even as restaurants reopened across the U.S.

The largest food-delivery company by sales in the U.S. reported revenue at $4.89 billion last year, up 69% from the previous year when nationwide shutdowns propelled blistering growth for DoorDash and its food-delivery rivals. Revenue for the three months through December stood at $1.3 billion, up 34% from the same quarter in 2020.

The pandemic served as an unexpected boon for DoorDash as consumers grew more accustomed to the ease and convenience of ordering meals and groceries through apps. To capitalize on the shift, DoorDash expanded its offerings to deliver everything from groceries to alcohol and pet food. It also expanded its logistics partnerships, delivering orders placed directly on the websites retailers including Walmart Inc. and Macy's Inc.

The continued strength of food-delivery and its expansion into new segments led DoorDash to forecast the total value of orders on its platform to grow to as much as $50 billion in 2022, from about $42 billion in 2021. The estimate is in line with the consensus for 2022 from analysts surveyed by FactSet.

While DoorDash beat revenue projections in the fourth quarter and in 2021, its loss and adjusted earnings fell short of Wall Street's forecasts.

DoorDash's investments into new categories and in growing the business overseas affected the company's bottom line, Chief Financial Officer Prabir Adarkar said in an interview. The service expanded to Japan and Germany last year and agreed to purchase Finland-based food-delivery startup Wolt Enterprises Oy late last year, a deal that is expected to close in 2022.
